div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: ESTABLISHED 1880.
SATURDAY, JANUARY 19, 1907.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
div.p: The recent pronouncement of the Italian Chamber of Commerce on the proposed modification of the Capitluations appears to us to have been based either on an erroneous version or on a misundertstanding of Lord Cromer's propsoals as set forth in his report for 1905. It was never the intention of the great statesman who has so long and so brilliantly represented the British Empire in Egpt to hand over the members of the European colonies in Egypt to the tender mercies of entirely native Courts. Indeed any such intention was openIly disclaimed by H.B.M.'s Agent, and while we are very ready to acknowledge the attractions of a policy of marking time in regard to the Capitulations we cannot see that Con. servatism of this sort is likely in the long run to benefit the country. Even granting that the Capitulations question is temporarily shelved, it is bound to be brought up again, and in our opinion ita reappearance may quite conceivably be connected with revival of Nationalist agitation. Thus far, it is true, the extreme wing of the Egyptian Nationalist party has, if anything, opposed Lord Cromer's schemes and rather Daively defended its action on the ground that the removal of the international check-however harmful its continued existence to the best interests of Egypt would allow the British Government freer hand to the greater deltiment-according to the journalistic mouthpieces of the above-mentioned party-of Egypt and the Egyptians. We do not, of course, share this view, but we should like to point out that, under certain conditions which can easily be imagined, a demand for the abolition of the Capitulations might become very important "plank" in the Nationalist platform of the future, "Surely it would be more prudent for the critics of the proposed modifications to take this possibility into account.

But, abandoning hypotheses as to the future, to what do the suggestions of Lord Cromer amount ? Simply to the absorption by Britain of the Capitulations. Our correspondent "Africa nus" pointed this out in an able letter which we published in our issue of Monday, and added that some species of guarantee of the permanency of the British Occupation would be demanded by the European population of Egypt before its individual members consented to forego the rights which they now possess. This criticism undoubtedly goes to the root of the whole matter. Our policy in Egypt is based-and, we may add, can only be justifiably based on the assumption that we are here as instructors who have agreed to leave the school when the pupils have given proofs of their ability to make their own way in the world. How, then, can we give any guarantee of the permanence of our occupation 1 Our agreeement with France does not appreciably alter the situation. By its provisions we are committed to a self-denying policy as regards changes in the political situation of the country, while our political predominance therein is at the same time admitted. We are therefore debarred, to a self-denying policy as regards changes in the political situation of the country, while our political predominance therein is at the same time admitted. We are therefore debarred, on the one band, from declaring & protectorato of the country (we assume, of course, the nonoccurrence of any political cataclysm), and, on the other, we are bound by our promises and the whole tenor of our administration to work for the realisation of the formula "Egypt for the Egyptians," however long we may have to wait till the country is ripe for self-government,

If it be assumed that the provisions of the Anglo-French Agreement do not deal with the difficulty to which we have alluded is it not possible for some formula to be discovered by French and British statesmen which will solve the dilemma without any infraction of the Anglo-French Agreement or of our obliga tions towards Egypt 1 We require formula which will explicitly assert the continuance of the political bond between Great Britain and Egypt without in the least prejudicing the de facto rights of the former country to grant to the latter, it and when it becomes ripe for it, a greater measure of internal freedom from foreign control. In brief can Egypt for the Egyptians" be reconciled with the demand of our correspondent for a guarantee of the per manency of the Oocupation

That Egypt is not yet ripe for self-govern ment is our firm conviction, and, despite the eloquence of certain orators and journalists, we cannot believe that we shall ourselves see the day when Egyptians will be entirely able to dispense with foreign advice as to the management of their own affairs. But if and when that day comes, what is to be our position! Are we to abandon Egypt to the Turk or to the tender mercies of any ambitious Power with a taste for foreign advonture! Be the future Egyptian Government never so pacific, never so liberal, it must incur with all weak States a fatal liability to foreign aggression, and we shall have played Egypt a sorry trick if we abandon her to the mercy of tho first comér. Again, there is the strategical question-can we, can any Power with Great Eastern interests ever be indifferent to the future of the State which will one day owa the Suez Canal ! But we are plunging into the slough of speculative welt-politik. Enough that we have given with all diffidence our interpretation of a very complex situation.

div.head: DRUSES VERSUS BEDOUINS.
THE RECENT FIGHTING.
div.p: The recent encounter between Draser and Bedouins in the Vilayet of Syria appears to bave been of a very serijos nature, the loss of life being far more heavy than is usually the osno in inter-tribal warfare. The skilfol tactics and straight shooting of the Droses appear to bave completely rooted their opponents, who were doubtless inore than sorprised to find their chargos received with saob remarkable stendiDesa by the bill men. The Horan Druses, it may be remembered, gave the Turkish Government and its Bedouin and Cirosasian allies considerable trouble io 1894. Their nombers! bave inoreased since ther, and they are now extremely we'l armed with Martini and maga sine rifles.

During the frontier dispate the Turkish forces in Syria were inereased mainly by drafts from he Vth Army Corps and a considerable pomber of man dispatched to Akabs vd Ma'au. Nope tbe less the Turkish forces in the Vilayeta of Beyroat, Aleppo, and Damasoos did not by any means reach the imposing total of 80,000 men given by Mokhtar Pasha, and the constant drafte of Syrian conscripts to Yemen and Macedonia must have caused a fortber dimination of effe stives. The 9ib Division of the Nizim is now at Series in Baropean Turkey, while over 20 battalioor of infantry were dispatched in 1904 and 1905 to the seat of war in Arsbia, to retara with the strength of companies or never to return at all.

It is this military weakness of the central goveroment that may explain the signs of onrest pow visible in the Haurda, bat there is no reason to expect this weakness to be of loog continuanoe. Toe connection of the Aleppo line with the main Tarkish railway system, which will probably be completed in the next few years, appears to us as certain to be follow ed by an inorense of the garrison of the vilayet.

div.head: MR. ROBERTSON AND FANATISM.
div.p: M.J. M. Rybertson, M.P., we hear, visited the Coptic school at Dirmsh, a few days ago, in the company of Sheikh Tewfik Hamoudi, who was recently requested by Sheikh Shakir to abstain from uttering inflammatory discourage in the moq e: st Alexandria. Mr. Robertson is said to have asked the papils whether there were any fanaticism in the district, to which they promptly, and Datarally, answered, "No."

div.head: MINISTRY OF EDUCATION.
div.p: Our Assonan Correspondent writes : The Minister of Bluestion arrived here by steemer from Lexor on the 15th, and proceeded direct I to the Government school accompanied by the mondir, sub-mondir, msmont, and an inspector. Next morning he visited the kattabs, and at 10 he was at the Coptio school. All the popila of the school, numbering 280, were present and passed a very revere examination in English, Arabio, geography, ard arithmetic. Afterwards. | be signed his name in the visitors' book, andccongratulated the headmaster on the great 1000ess of the school. The Minister was so pleared at the reception accorded him that be gave the boys s holiday. Yesterday morning, be visited a kattab at G siret Assouan belong. Jing to a fiki named Sheikh Naggar. At 10 o'clock he left by his steamer for Luxor.

div.head: NOTES FROM KENEH.
div.p: Our Kereb Correspondent telegraphs that football match was played between teams representing keneh and Sohag Government Schools yesterday, in the presence of a great gathering of potables, efficials and Eng'ish fanctionaries, besides the Minister of Bdoor tion, who arrived just in time. Gaafar Wali BA.. Pabance Inspector, acted as referee. Beveb won the game by three goals.

The Minister to-day visited the Government School, the Moadirieb, and be Tribunals. His Excellency congratulated the headmaster of the school on the popils' smartnes. He left to day at 11 a... for Sobag.

div.head: AGITATION AGAINST EXTRADITION
div.p: A good deal of indignation has been aroused in Alexandria by the new that three individuals, who are said to be Russian refugees. have been arrested, and are about to be embarked on a steamer here for Odonsa. Telegrams were dispatched yesterday to Lord Cromer asking his Lordship to intercede in the matter, and "in the name of the humanitarian principles and constant liberal doctrine of England" to prevent the extradition of these men.

To one of these telegrams, Lord Cromer has sent a telegram in reply, in which he states that the three individuals in question are accused of having made preparations to blow up Russian trading vessel in the port of Alexandria. If, says his Lordship, investigations show that they are Russian subjects they will be handed over to their consular anthorities, who of course have every right to deal with them according to the laws of their country. Otherwise they will be liable to be tried by the Egyptian Tribunale. Lord Cromer adds that he has received "uumerous telegrams on this subject."
The promoters of the agitation in favour of the Russians, however, are not satisfied with this reply, and a public meeting is to be held to night to concert-further measures.
As we go to press we learn that a large depotation, composed mainly of stockbrokers, is marching on the British Consulate in order to make a demonstration.

div.head: GOLD FOR ENGLAND.
div.p: A considerable sum of gold, amounting to over £370,000, is being exported by the National Bank of Egypt and the other Egyptian banks to London. We understand that it has been earmarked at the Bank of England for account of the lodis Couvoil, and we have good reasons for believing that the Egyptian banks naturally did not part with the gold except at the market price of excbange.

div.head: ABYSSINIAN BANK.
div.p: We understand that Mr. MacGillivray, till now Governor of the Bank of Abyssinin at Addis Abeba, has decided not to return to Abyssinis. Mr. MacGillivray is at present on a visit to Upper Egypt.

div.head: SMOKEN AMHARIC.
div.p: Amharic, owing to its wide use on the Sudap-Abyssinian frontier, is being stodied by some of the Anglo Sudanese officials.

The Cambridge University Press bave in hand a series of books which represent the first attempt to introduce to England spoken Ambario, the work of Mr. C. H. Armbruster, of the Sudan Civil Service. Ambario is the language most widely spoken and written in Abyssipin at the present day. It is also spokon in the adjoining Italian oolonies, the Pronoh Somali Coast proteotorate, and the eastern provinces T of tbe Sodan. Colloquial knowledge being the end in view,overy A mbario word is phonetioally expressed in roman letters as well as given in the pative character. Part I. is concerned with grammar; Part II. with an Baglish-Ambario vocabulary and phrases; while Part III. I contains idiomatic expressions and illustrations, Mr. Armbruster has been engaged apon this work for several years on the western frontier of Abyasinis.

div.head: SATISFACTORY PROGRESS
div.p: To judge alone by the figuras tabulated in the Customs rataror, last year was one of abnormal prosperity; and it is a prosperity the more particularly evident by the fact, which an important school of political economista invariably demand me the basis of national wealth, that exports exceed imports by LB. 866,485, which means, in the balance sheet of the country's cash-book, so much to the good in the profit and loss account.

Thus, the total importe for 1906 were LE 24,7 10,795, as against LE. 21,864,079 in 1905, an increase of LE. 2,446,719 ; and the exports for 1906 were LR 24,877,280, as against L.E. 20,860,285, an increase of LE. 4,616,995. Por 1906, therefore, the surplus of exports over imports was LE. 866,485 as stated; whereas, per contra, fur 1905 imports exceeded exports by L.E. 1,203,791.

Of the total imports of L.E. 24,010,795 for 1906, the chief items were : textiles, LE 6.100,846; metals and hardware, L.B.8,868, 747; cereals, vegetables, and floor, L.E. 8,071,696; wood and cow, L.B. 3,027,847.

The lion's sbate wout to Great Britain, with total of LE. 8,056,448, of which LE. 3,680,059 were textiles, L.B 1,768,658 hardware and L.B. 1,281,709 coal and wood. Turkey comes next with LB. 3,041,844, made ap, inter alia, of LE. 826,893 of cereals, vegetables, and floor ; LB. 729,162 of livestock and animal produce; L.B. 448,440 coal and wood. Germany, which the tabulator always ranks next to Great Britain, sent no more than LR 1,307,675 worth of goods, of which hardware figures for LB. 510,210, and textiles L.B. 202,369. France is third in the race, with L.B 3,785,248, in which agricultural produce takes first place with L.B.863,859 ; her textile exports are L.B 524,589,

Turning DOW to exports, L. B. 24,877,980, rooftop and textiles bead, the list with L.B.20,696,007. Half of this went to Great Britain, i.e., LB. 10,818,963. For December, 1906, the total cotton and textile exported was L. B.8,776,848,LB. 2,001,658 going to Great Britain, - total increase over December, 1905, of L.E. 1,506,180. A great gap intervenes between this and the next most important item of Bgyptian export, namely,agricultural produce, which was invoiced for LB. 2,871,663, an increase of L.E 141,106 over 1906. Molt of this went to England.

div.head:
THE SERVANT QUESTION IN
EGYPT.
div.byline: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
div.p: Sir,- I am pleased to learn by the letter of "Another Old Resident" ia your issue of yesterday that this important subject is being taken ap by your readers. The sobeme suggested by him for the introduction of Goane: servants might serve to meet the demand for deceat servants at 1848onable rates of pay, and I feel sure that were it possit le to engage such 1. class in Egypt there would be plety of applicants for their services. The diffi sulty lies chiefly in establishing the organisation for bringing them into the country, and this in the onse of most private persone would be extreme. Would it be possible to invoke the aid of a British Chamber of Commerce to arrange for the importation of such servants : A part from the above schemes and any servants tbat might tbereby come to this country, we most of course remain in as great measure de pendent on the native for domestic service, and surely it is inoumbent on the Governmen', whieb looks after the comfort of its officials to the extent of supplying some of them with private residences, to recognise its responsibi. lity in this matter. What is impossible for private individuals is comparatively easy for a Government Administration, and there is nothing to prevent the drafting of sbort deeree to enact that every native servant in the service of a Biropean must be registered under penalty of a fide, to be increased in a reogrrence of an offence against the regulation. Besides tegistration of names every now place entered or left would have to be note 1, with any remarks necessary. Masters would aid the system by Advising the registry offi e of the cessation of their employment of a servant and might give the reasons of his leaving.
These are, of course, merely suggestions : the details of the scheme would have to be worked out by the competent legal offiers of the Government.

Such a system of registration would not be attended with the elements of odiom and disgrace which are connected with the Anthropometrioal Bureau. The fees payable on registration would probably make the offi se self-supporting, and it could be included in the Budget of any of the minor administra tione, Booh as the Slavery epartment, whose officers would doubtless bellad to spa e from the time allotted to the discharge of their present arduous daties & low miontes Dow and then for the ultimate control of so useful a reform. I sm, eto,

div.head: INAUGURATION OF WINTER PALACE.
div.p: Luxor, Satarday, 10.30 am. This morning the night train from Cairo brought down the directors of the Upper Egypt Hotels Company and a bomber of their I guests in order to attend the opening of the new Luxor Winter Palace Hotel. Tbeinango. ration will take place this evening, and great preparations have been made to vender the OOCH NIOD worthy of the palatial building, description of which will no doubt internet or rendere

Built within two hundred yards of the bistorio Temple, its long winga faring close upon the river with its magnificent view, this latest addition to M. Pagnon's players in Upper Egypt is perhaps the best and most elaborately-redeemed botel within the land of Egypt, and will accommodate some 900 guests. Facing the river on the west the whole of the back of the building looks over the garden and fertile ground to the mountains on the Bas", so that throughout the day the brilliant health giving superbone is pouring into the balconies and terraces in either one direction or the other. A hoge out stretched horse shoe terrace built on colonnades makes a welcome lounge overlooking where Nile steamers have their moorings, and double marble staircases lai to the entrance-ball. The internal arrangements lepe k volumes for the experience of M. Pagoon and his energetic manager, M. Louis Sebaiob, the latter of bom has been so largely responsible for the success of various of the botels in both Luxor and Assouan.

On the basement floor is the fine bar and | billiard-room with entrance from botel and outside, and behind it are the thousand and ore departments given over to the service of the hotel. There are store rooms and wide cellars capacious enough to stand a siege. Kitobeds and bothers' shop, vegetable app, separate seallerier, refrigerators, linen room, oto., all byilt to role and in accordance with most up-to-date requirements. On the same floor, too, are many bedrooms and bandsome sunny apartments for the use of ladies' msida and valets as well as the dining-room accommodation for those employed upon the staff.

The entrance hall is in the centre of the building and from it leads the wide marble staircase to the upper floor. Another large lounge leads also out of it, but well away from draught, and where it er joys the foll b'r za of the sun through its enormous windows. The music room and ladies' drawing-room are also on this for, the former giving on to a wide expanse of terreos at the back. The handsome restaurant with its large windows locks over the river, and the reading and waiting rooms have also the Fame view and the same luxurious English fireplaces.

One wing on his floor is devoted to bedroom accommodation, and to every third the room is a most complete bath and toilet room; while at the end of the long corridor is a well planned private suite of apartments, including beacons entrance ball, saloor, and three or four good bedrooms. Similar private suites are to be found at either end of the corridors on the upper floors; and there are two most luxurious buites for princely visitors, ove over the entrance, and one at the back of the hotel, both of which own roomy terraces and every convenience that ingenuity or suggest. Nearly all the bedrooms are provided with balconies and all the larger ones have also fireplaces; and bathrooms, sto., are most conveniently placed.

The entire hotel is surrounded by a garder, and mouth of the fruit and vegetables are grown upon the spot, for not only does the manage meat supply its own requirements but also those of the various steamboats which moor ja its vicinity. When all is completed there will be tennis and racquet lawns included: and in time the garden will become another vista of beauty like onto that of the ar jointing Luxor Hotel, which is a riot of gorgeous colouring and sweetly scented ff wers. An annexe is also being built with an engine house to supply the electricity, and bere also will be & model dairy and laundry besides many rooms for the European staff of the botel, private dragomane, aod so forth.
The hotel has been completely finished and is ready to receive goeste in every part except the third floor.

The arrangements and reservations on the railway journey last night from Cairo were made under the superintendence of Mr. H. W. Tite, the popular representative of the Inter pational Sleeping Car Company in Egypt. Mr. and Mrs. Tito were among the party who arrived here this morning.

Mr. Harrison, general manager of Messrs. Thos Cook and Son (Egypt), Limited, and Mr. Mazbach were among the directors of the Upper Egypt Hotels Company who arriv. ed here by this morning's train from Cairo. Mr. George Nangoviob and Mr. Charles Baebler, the other directors, were capable to come. The party from Cairo Numbered twenty five and invaded Judge Rayle • d Mr. N. Spathis. Mr. Flood, the secretary of the company, came down from Cairo to attend the inauguration. I am sorry to say, however, that M. Pagoon, the managing director, will be capable, through indisposition, to attend the inaugural banquet, to which about 150 guests have been invited.

div.head: A PETITION.
div.byline: To the EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE'
div.p: Sir,--Within this letter ab app iextion of complaint is offered by na to
(1) The Chief of the High Board of Admibitration of the Eryp'ian State Rsilw.yr.
(2) The Director General of the Egyptien State Railways
(3) The Traffic Manager of the Egyptian State Railways

(4) The Adviser of the Ministry of Ficano, We, having knows that your newspaper is the most liberal and notable and well known for helping the plaintiffs like os, bave one with the hope of approving our demands, which are bigby justified and we formally thank you heartly.
THE SERVANTS OF THE
EGYPTIAN STATE TRAINS.
The following is the "application of complaint" referred to:

Sir, - We, the undersigned guards: beg to bring before your notice the following con plaints which we cannot bear any longer. We are formed between two miseries in watching all day and night long, a bard wurk which gives us no results for a little red or even enjoyment on official holidays, andeven w wolk merited sleep during the night off duty; in such a onge it would have been better if we were dead and thats not see others of this world getting their holidays so pleased. After being on daty for a week daring which we soffor the strongest bard-hips, perhaps more this a conviot's, we go home ti-el and wrot hed, ogr eyes closed with the fatigue of our work. We fiad no time to speak to our family but to mqrest them to wake of ap in time to attend to our work thy following porning, the giving us a night hoʻidayahich wa cannot enjoy. Naturally under the hardships wake up not better the presiding nigb, in fear that we may miss the train and got fixed with a fine consisting nearly one day's pay. This is our existence aod that of our family. Moreover the daily living expenses: "uador the high prices of food that Cairo is victimel, are beyond our resob with the poor wager we receive: we ongnot express the life we have to endura, this gives us another point of complaining as we work so maob aad gaia bate so little

The ordinary pay of a gaard is £4, 600 mill., if he is not passed andør fizes or he has not to pay the price of some lost articles with the brakeman. Ia this case can this poor sum soffice to the needs of a person who daring a whole month has to pass his nights in different towost Supposing he can pull himself through, what if he has to help his family or his wife and childrenNo answer can ba given to this, but the approval of the hardships we cannot any longer datain. To show you that our expenses are more than what we get, let us ask you the following questions ; Can we find a boose for five persons less than PT. 150 monthly 1 Don't we require an ardeb of flur at P.T. 201 Don't we require moreover at least 1516. botter at 120 PT. 1. and some other expenses am dating at least at P.T. 3001 This, then, gives us a very good-ground to complain about our position and wait upon your judgement.

Our sort which is the fame since the last 30 years classes ns in the same grade of men entitled to benefit societies, whereas we pass onr life in the Administration's service till our health becomes weak or we are the victims of some accident. That's our position in the Government service is much inferior to that: of other employés, whose position bas been lately altered. We have no hopes to the pension liat either as we shall never be able to accomplished the quarter of the period of service entitled in these fonoticp: by the continuation of this bard work which les ven us every day in * wretched condition. We hope that you will kindly give us your help in this matter, having aeon our situation in the a few words. This help is eagerly expected and we shall for over and ever be redeemable to you.

div.head:
JAMAICA EARTHQUAKE.
KINGSTON HARBOUR SINKING.
CITY WILL PROBABLY SLIP INTO SEA.

div.p: According to seablegram received from the Governor of Jamaica yesterday evening the earthquake was confined to the three parishes of Kingston, Port Royal, and St. Andrew.
Up to yesterday 843 borislav have taken place in Kingston. 500 persons have been removed to hospital. A few bodies are still covered in the roin.
Some looting has taken place, but the population are wonderfully patient, though liatlona.
Correspondents state that the harbour in soaking and it is feared that the city will slip into the ses
The Palm Point and Port Royal lighthouses have disappeared.
The Gorms liner Prise Waldemar in Mahare The Hamburg Amoriono line bas Jaspended sailings to Jamaics owing to the change in the ocean bød.
An American torpedo-boat, with medical supplies, and the battleships Mimori and
(Reuter)
The grounding of the Prie: Waldemar is denied.
(Reuter)
According to news received from Kingstor, Majo Hardyman in dead.
Sixty one British and whites are now known to have been killed.
The French rainer Kleber, which is at Martinique, has been ordered to proceed to Kingston with relief stores.
(Reuter)
The Chamber and the Sanste have addressed their condolences to Bagland.fr the Kingston earthquake.
The oraiset Keber, which is at present at Port de Prapca, is taking provinione to Kingston.
(Havas)
The "Cologne Gazette" state- that the Degrege st Kingston are getting drunk and roatan to maiat in the rescue work. The whites have taken refuge on the steamers. (Havas)
Two earthquake shocks were felt at Oban (Sootland) yesterday. Houses were spoken. The population is solar med. (Reuter)
Reports from the outlying towns that show tidal waves inundated Aneths, where houses were swept away. Richmond has been destroyed by fire. (Reuter)

div.head:
U.S.A. AND CANADA.
A SIGNIFICANT VISIT.

div.p: Mr. Root will arrive at Ottawa tomorrow on a week's visit to Lord Grey. Though the visit will estensibly be a social one, as it immediately follows a prolorged and important interchange of communications between London, Washington, and Ottawa, it is believed in well-informed quarters here that it will be likely to lead to a settlement of various outstanding disputes. (Reuter)

Our own family doctor gave Os so hope whatever-in fact, one day became and told me that she had only a few hours to live. It was droopy, he said, from which abe was suffering.

Everyone who saw her felt sure that she couldn't possibly last long. She had to be propped up in bed with a rest, and 9 pillows, to prevent ber from booking. She was so swollen that, when the bed had to be made it took 4 parsons to lift ber ont. The doctor said she must have weighed at least 20 stone. She is only 25 years of age.

The weather yesterday was seasonably cold, dull, and rainy. During the night it became boisterous, light, westerly gales blowing wit hgreat force, and the sea being rough. The morning was equally, but indications point to its being more settled, though cold.

div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: Qu'est ce que c'est BOVRIL?
BOVRIL est le produit garanti du meilleur bétail qui existe.
C'est un repas à la minute qui protège contre les intempéries.
"BOVRIL" et "Bonne Cuisine" sont deux mots qui disent la même chose.

BOVRIL répond a une nécessité; il est non seulement une boisson delicieuse et saine, mais il est encore indispensable pour préparer instantanement des soupes et sauces appétisantes. Bovril n'a pas de rival pour corser les plats les plus récherches.
BOVRIL répare l'organisme fatigué.

PRICE 2fc. hot
A New Issue has been found necessary within Six Months.
Letter from Sir Rudolph von Siatin.

Dear Mr. War, - Your delightful and most interesting book on the SOudan has reached me. I congraulate you heartily on the excellent manner in which the work is written and illustrated. All of us who have done our little best to regenerate the country, after its terrible misfortunes, have received more than kind treatment at your hands...I don't suppose anyone realises more than I do the change that has come over the Sudan since my old and tyrannical master the Phalifa disappeared from the scene. Your description of the Peace and Progress, is in fact, a sequal to my Fire and Sqord in the Sudan.
With kindest regards, believe me,
Yours sincerely,
RUDOLF V. SLATIN.

div.head: Cotons
div.p: Il est toujours ennbyeox pour le lecteur, et nous nous en rendons parfaitement compte, de voir certaines questions revenir constsmment egr le tapin, mais nécessité fait souvent loi et c'est notre cas apjourd'hui.

Il do D'agit pullement de discuter, mais tout simplement de faire comprendre à ces quel ques personne auprès desquelles prévaut ko fausse idée qu'on alheureux, voué aux cbro niques commerciales, doit invariablement écrire dans le sens qui convient à chacun de ceux qui lo liwept (& be difficile que celle-la) que nous De son mes pas là pour plaire aox uns et aux autres, mais bien pour donner une relation ausi fidèlo que possible de ce qoi Be passe autour de nous sur le marché, tout en exposant notre opinior, mais de façon à ménager toutes les suscep'ibilités.

Nous reconnaissons que parfois nous nous sommes laissés aller à des écarta de plume, mair, question de tem, érament, on n'est pas toujours maitre de soi quand on ne laisse entrainer polémiquer. Dans tous les cas, noua prioba nos lecteurs de ne pas trop nous en vouloir quand il nous arrive de tomber dans ce défaut, car BODA tenons à leurs sympatbies, sans compter qu'il n'entre jamais dans notre intention d'être, de propos délibéré, désagréable à qoi que ce soit
Ceci dit, passong à la revue du marobe.

La tenue du marché pendaut la semaine qui vient de fioirté extraordinaire, ep 08 sens que la fermeté qui a régié d'un bout & l'autre a eté vraiment surprenante, aveo tous les élémenta qui, raisonnablement, devaient s'opposer à tout mouvement ou & toute tentative de baunse; wsie la spéculation en a décidé antrement et, il faut bien le Trocnnaitre, elle , relativement, assez bien réussi daus son but consistant maintenir pour le moins les prix atteinta.

Pour la matinée de samedi, elle a été admi.. rablement servie par les raobsts très copieux da quelqa6a.gros faisaurs de notre place, 18obats qui ont permis à des haussiers da Caire do liquider leur positions dans des conditions inespérées. Les prix obtenus par les vendeurs ont varié entre 21 5/8 et 91 8/4 poor la plus grande partie des réalisations, mais la c!Otore, sur la faiblesse da disponible et de l'avantbourse de Liverpool, t'a eu lieu qo's 21 9/16. Quand même, elle Lous laissait au bénéfice de

Landi xyant été jour férié à l'occasion da premier de Yan orthodoxe, la reprise des affsires n'a eu lien que Mardi. A cause de 40 points perdus par l'Amérique dans l'entre tempa, toát le monde s'attendait à une première nos des plos désorganisées ; mais, spies on recol momentané à 21 3/8, les bxossiera, prenant prétexte des fortes exportations qui avaient en lien, ont réagi et sont parvenus à maintenir le Mars à 21 17/32.

Le lendemain, c'est la reprise d'Amérique qui a fourni l'appui nécessaire pour em_ @aber toute résotion, tandis que Jeudi, ce sont le gronben ventes en Exyptiens di-ponibles à Liverpool, ninai que les prévisions comme em barquement pour la sem sine, dépassés d'ure maridte sebsib'e par la suite, qui nous ont vala la bagrao da M 21 21/32, en passant par le cours de 21 28787.
Comme on le voit, toutes les séances avaient été savez intéresuante, mais celles qui ont été

les plus attrayantes, ce sont, sane contredit, celles d'aujourd'bui, la première toute de fer meté à cause de la bunne tenue de New York at da relevé du mouvement bel domadaire de notre place donnant 88,000 Balles d'exportations, au lieu des 39,000 prévues deux joats soparsvant, et la seconde finissant en binne de 7/39 sur le maximum de la matinée et de S.S. sur la o Olure de 1 heure, soit à 21 1/2.

Après tout, o'est encore une avance de 8/39 qui reste sequise con me résumé des varistions de la semaine; mais, qu'on le veoilla on non, le marobé de ce soir a été bien mauvais et les demandes de 40 et 100,COU cantars la fois de la part de ceux qoi voulsier cours, n'ont servi qu'à encourager les vendeurs qui, par des pogoeta bien moindrer, de 1,000 # 5,000 caplars, ont fini par peser sur les Bours tout en obligeant les boursier à ne retirer beaucoup plus sehargés qu'il ne l'auraient voulu ! Pour le moment at jorqu'à nouvel ordre des choses, la tendance reste done per brillante.

Certes, tout pent changer de nouveau et des demain matin même; mais, en atteudant, et pour DOON coutrecarra, Dons arons, en debors de la piètre tenue de l'Américain, les 3 faits suivants : la persistance de la filature dans son abstention quasi completo, le marque d'apimation de marché da disponible at, par dessus tout, les continuelles ventes des arbitragistes qui, pour ne pas être très importantes prises isolément, n'en sont pas moins en voia de fioir par représenter un total qui aura son mot à dire pur la situation. Seul un réveil de la demande de la part de la filatura poprraiti former contre-poide à l'effet de ses ventes et les arêter pent être, mais de réveil de paroit goede probable, et pour longtemps, avec les cours régnants.
L'activité da marehé des contrats n'a pas été bien grande ni surtont suivie.

Les reports sont restés à sec près les mêmes optre janvier et mars, mais ont encore diminue pour les mois éloignés, do fait que quelquesli arbitragistes pemblent tonjours pencher pour les ventes sur les derniers mois de la campagne. C'est peut être la prudence qui les induit || s'assurer placement d'argent qui leur Bemble suffisamment avantageox déjs.

Dans notre dernière revne, nous svons par & de la possibilité de la réception de Janvier 1 Une partie de la position qui existait été reportée, ople nutre a été liquidée, mais il reste toujoors une partie qui est en train d'être reçue, qui n'exercera toutefois anoon effet sur le mar, obé, attendu qu'en l'eepèce il n'est pas qaektion d'une mare ivre spécolative goaleor que, mais purement d'une affaire de report ; les ventes sur Mars remplaceront le Janvier qu'on dancevoir et voi à tout.

L'activité sur la nouvelle évolte a été bien plan grande que sur l'ancienne et les positions prises sur le Novembre s'élèveut à des chft es respectables. Le décorvert n'est pas trop tranqaille et ce qui le prouve c'est la fermeté des conta nêne quand les mois rapproobés sont faibles et en baiese, et il est de fait que si les acheteurs étaient réellement en manure de soutenir et d'aller de l'avant, ils feraient jolimont donner les vendeurs en blanc, et cela malgré l'absence de tout appoi du dehors.
Novembre a fini à 18 17/32.

Manchester antonop, dit-on, de la base sur les filés é, yptiens, mais au topd la vérité semble être que les filatedts, engagés pour longtemps, de consentent des ventes qu'aux tisseurs qui veulent bien se laisser égorger en payant par doessité les prix fabuleux qu'on esige d'eux.

En Amérique o'est la baisse qai fait du ebemin à cause de mouvement énorme de la récolte qai commence à faire croire que Neill pourrait bien avoir raison avec son estimation de 13.600.000 balles minimam. La filatare a besa aobeter, il y a trop de cotoo.

Le marché da disponible a manqué spoore one fois d'animation, mais il fait farmo ot on hausse de 1/4 & 1/8 tallari per les Mit Afili, de 5'8 pour les provenances Haute-Egypte, taras et en faveur malgré la rédaction de la diffé rence entre elles et les qualités correspondanter de la Basse Rgypte a 1/2 et 3/4 de tallari, de 1/2 pour les Abassi et de 1/8 3/8 pour les Joannovich, les classements supérieurs étant les plus favorisés.

Le monvement de notre récolto continue @tre exceptionnellement grand : Nous sommes deja i 5 1/millions de cantars comme recettes et. 98.000 balles de sorplas dans les exportations oe qui fait que l'ex édest du strok sor l'année passée n'est que de cantars 330.000 environ.

D'anonne, prenant pour base la diminution dans les reostte de cette sem sine, s'amusent de nouvean parler d'ane récolto de 6.500.00 onntars environ ; lear erreur et profonde et une diminution acoidentelle et provisoire de signifie rien : il reste daes l'intérieur autant de ooton que l'année dernière à cette date et leur désillusion ne peut etre que complete le jour où le chiffre de 7.000 000, généralement préconike, commencers à devenir une réslité.
Les exportations ont atteint 38.000 balles pour la semaine, dépassant de la sorte les pronontios de 6.000 balles, contre un total de 81.000 balles l'ono66 dernière pour la période correspondante.

Cette augmentation tout à fait inattendue provient du fait qu'il voite d'une décision nouvelle, tous les arriérés ont été réglé, d'ot froe par ls Douane. D'ailleurs, il ne s'agit pas dans l'espace d'une mesure transitoire, msig bien de quelque chose de définitif ; dorénavant les embarquements seront réglés jpar par jour de façon que si parfoip i restait des suspens, il ne seraient que depen d'importance et seraient liquidé le lendemain. C'est la une bonne nouvelle qui aora le double avantage de permettre à l'avenir des appréciations plus exactes de ce qui peut être embargné pendant la semaine et de balmer obcême temps les nerfs à osux qui ont émis In sotte prétention que les probables doivent étre tonjours conformes aux réels, parlant de la sorte comme des mattres d'éoole, pleins de théorie, mais ignorant le premier mot de ce qui est de fait en pratique.

Liverpool a été assez favorable aux égyptions dispovibles comme ventes, mais comme prix, le spot, après une baisse de 1/16, n'a fait que revenir à 10 S.S. Sar les futurs, par contre, il y a hausse de 8/64 sur le janvier qui est coté à 10 14/64.

Les Américains aussi ont été actifs ; sur les COUTP, cependant, il y a de la baisse, la oots d'étant que de 5.56 pour le spot, 5.49 pogr le Janvier Février et 5.48 pogr le Mai Jain, soit respectivement 10, 9 et 11 points de baisse.

div.head: Graines de Coton.

Hull avait recale à £ 6. 12/6 mais de nonvean la oota est de £6. 18,9, et s'est à la bausse des hailes que l'on doit oatte danande. En contrats il ne se fait que pea d'affairer, Joapéonlation, absorbé par les cotons, De montrant que peu d'intérêt pour la graine. Les conre, néanmoins, restent forms at le Février Mars fioit à P.T. 71 10/40.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Il y a une grande amélioration de la situstion monétaire. La tension, qui n'avait doare d'entra ver la marebe des affaires, & beaucoup diminné, comme l'atteste la refootion du tanz privé d'escompte en Angleterre de 5 & 4.5/8 1% De son côté, la Banque d'Angleterre a paramenor lo rien de 6* 5% giace à l'augmen tation or wante de sa réserve do 40 45 1/4 % Cotte dé' ento, qui s'est produite subite ment, n'a pas encore sa le temps de faire son. tir ses effets, et c'est la raison pour laqaelle | les valeurs égyptiennes en particulier n'ont pas encore profité d'une ples-valae sor le marebé de Londres.

Loi la disette monétaire disparait graduelle ment et les statistiques de la donape concernant l'importation et l'exportation de l'or en 1906 vous sont un garant que la précieux métal se trouve en Brypte en quantité bien plus considérable qu'auparavant. A l'importatior, il y a 4295.187 L.R. de plos qu'on 1905, et à l'exportation 1.802.233 L.R. de moins. Cos deux cb free combinée ensemble constituent ope d fférence de plus de 6 millions de livres à l'avantage du 1906. Cet accroissement de no. méraire sora évidemment on profond retentissement sur la cote de nos valeurs, lorsque le moment sera vana poor ses détenteurs de le faire fractifier.

En dépit do oes considérations favorablea, la semaine n'a pas été brillante sor notre place. une tendance gévérale à réaliser s'est manifestée, du moins au debat. Peat &re la spéoulation I veut elle sortir do t'tres qu'elle a imprademment poussé: an niveau dangereux pour rentrer sur d'aqtres plas solides et relativement dépréciés. Dans 06 088 Dous ne pouvons que la lover et souhaiter que ce travail d'éparation contivne aussi longtemps qu'il sera nécesssire, Le fait est que toate la oote a baisse d'ano facon appréciable, pour remonter partiellement Des deux derniers jours. Bu définitive, capea dant, c'est en baisse que nous o' orone, pois. que sur une cinquantaine de valeurs inscrites la cote officelle de notre bourse, 30 sont en baisse, 8 seulement en hausse e les autres demeurent stationnaires.

Les fluctuations les plus sensibles sont: à la baisse, la D-ferred Dalta qui perd 1/4 de livre 13, les ducreries 10 fr. 3 60, et les Jouissances Baux du Caire 4 Ir. 296; à la hausse, la Bière d'Alexandrie gaisagae 5 Ir. la Privile giée 225 et 8 fr. Jeare personne, veuve d'ufficier, que la mort de son mari et des revers de fortone obligent chercher un emploi, accepterait une place d'institutrice, de dame de compagnie on de gouvernante dans une bor ne famille ; ou à défaut, un poste de oxissière ou d'employée dans un burean.

div.head:

div.p: CATARRH of the kidneys is very much neglected disease. It is not until the disease Arm hold upon the kidneys that the patient begins to realise that there is some do rangement of these orgáns.
The light backaches, the feelings of lassitude, and other warning symptoms of kidney disease are overlooked.
They are not aerions enough to detain the patient from his regular work.
Even when he discovers that the kidBeys are affected, he does not recognize the diteliti as being caused by catarrh.
Ostarth is sometimes so very gradual in Its approach and Its earlier symptoms cause such slight discomfort that it is not noticed.
However, when it is onco firmly seated in the kidneys it becomes a difficult disease to exterminate,
Indeed, catarrh of the kidneys is more serious than catarrh affecting some of the other organs of the body.
In the kidneys it is liable to terminate in Bright's Disease ar diabetes, both of which are recognized as very serious ailments, it not fatal.

The thing to be done, when catarrh of the kidneys is discovered, is to take some internal, systemie catarrh remedy, one that reaches the very source of the catarrh and remove the cause of the difficulty.

Such remedy has been found in Peruns. It reaches estarrh, no matter where it may be 1oosted in the. body-whether inthe more exposed membranes of the nose and throat, or whether in the remotest part of the kidneys.
That Peruns is at once the safest and most reliable remedy for entarth of the kidneys is proven by the many testimonials written by those who have ex perienced its benefits.
The testimonials given here are only specimens of the many testimonials on our records, pertaining to the relief af forded by Peruns in severe cases of kidRoy trouble.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité met an wijndication la foornitore da sable pécessaires l'Entretien du Pavage de la Ville pendant la durée d'une année à partir da Jer Mars 1907.
Le cautionnement est fixé À LE 10.
Le cahier des charges est dépoé an baren de la Voirie où il pent être consulté par les intéresser tous les jours de 9 b. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offrea devront être adrersées Bons pli cacheté A Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 12 Février 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en se noe de la Délégation le même joor 5 hp.m..
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la men tion: "Soumission pour foumitore de sable.

Le cantionnement ou le reçu d'une henne, t'après les conditions da Oshier des charges, devra être remis réparément an Service de Is Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture Hes offres et au plus tard le 12 Février 1907 a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas los condi tions oi-dessos sera éosrtée.
Alexandrie, le 12 Janvier 1907.
L'Administrateur,
(Signé): W. P. CHATAWAY.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
